post_text:
Randolph’s Diversity and Inclusion Steering Committee (DISC) would like to invite members of the Randolph community to an Intimate Virtual Town Hall Meeting. The purpose of these town halls is to give you the opportunity to share your experiences in Randolph involving acts of bias based on race, religion, gender, disability, sexual orientation or ethnicity. We want to hear your thoughts on governance, and aspirations for the community.

If you are interested in participating, please go to http://bit.ly/RandolphDISC for more information.

DISC’s mission is to work towards the goal of eliminating acts of bias based on race, color, religion, gender, disability, sexual orientation or ethnicity in Randolph Township by understanding the causes and identify solutions. We seek to make recommendations to educate and train individuals, groups, organizations, institutions and businesses in order to interrupt and eradicate racism, bigotry and prejudice in Randolph Township.

post_text:
The Randolph Board of Education is seeking candidates to fill the unexpired term of a board member who recently resigned. Interested candidates are expected to be interviewed at the September 15, 2020 regular Board meeting in accordance with the process set forth in Board Policy 0143 (available online). After a state mandated background check, the person selected to fill the term would take office soon after and serve through the Organization Meeting in January 2022. Interested candidates should send their cover letter and resume via email to Mr. Gerald Eckert, Board Secretary at geckert@rtnj.org no later than September 4, 2020. For more information, please click here:

https://www.rtnj.org/domain/1319

#RandolphSchools #RandolphPride

post_text:
The Randolph High School leadership team is excited to honor the Class of 2020 during an in-person ceremony on July 8. Additional information regarding the event was sent directly to students and their families for review. Please review this information as it contains information regarding self regulating attendance at the event as well as staggered arrival times so the RHS leadership team can help ensure social distancing.

As it was shared previously, the ceremony will be for graduates only. However, as promised, the ceremony will be available via livestream. The link is below and will become active on the morning of July 8. The RHS leadership team has advised that they are hoping to start at 9:30 AM but has also apologized in advance for any delay due to the need for a "dress rehearsal!"

http://bit.do/RHS2020Graduation

If necessary, please stay tuned to alerts in the event the RHS leadership team needs to change the time due to weather.

#RandolphSchools #RandolphPride

post_text:
On June 23, 2020 the Board of Education approved the appointment of Tammy MacKay as Board President. Tonight, the Board of Education approved an amendment to district policy 0152 to allow the election of two Vice Presidents. Ms. Allison Manfred and Dr. Robert Soni will serve as Co-Vice Presidents. Congratulations to Ms. MacKay, Ms. Manfred, and Dr. Soni who will serve the Board of Education in their leadership capacities until the reorganization meeting in January 2021.

#RandolphSchools #RandolphPride
text:
On June 23, 2020 the Board of Education approved the appointment of Tammy MacKay as Board President. Tonight, the Board of Education approved an amendment to district policy 0152 to allow the election of two Vice Presidents. Ms. Allison Manfred and Dr. Robert Soni will serve as Co-Vice Presidents. Congratulations to Ms. MacKay, Ms. Manfred, and Dr. Soni who will serve the Board of Education in their leadership capacities until the reorganization meeting in January 2021.

#RandolphSchools #RandolphPride

post_text:
The New Jersey Technology and Engineering Educators Association (NJTEEA) has selected Randolph High School as a recipient of the 2020 100% Club Award. The 100% Club showcases schools with the highest level of commitment to professional development. Congratulations Anthony Emmons, Dominick LaCapra, Sanford Feld, David Thatcher, Duncan Crannell, Matthew Horner, Michael Pignaloso, and Christina Patella on this well deserved honor. We look forward to seeing what else you do to continue to cultivate a positive image of Technology & Engineering Education in our district.

#RandolphSchools #RandolphPride

post_text:
At the beginning of May, we honored RHS engineering teacher Duncan Crannell for his volunteer work 3D printing personal protective equipment components for essential workers. We have more exciting news. It is our pleasure to announce that the New Jersey Technology and Engineering Educators Association (NJTEEA) selected Mr. Crannell as a recipient of the organization's 2020 Image Award. The Image Award “honors individuals within the membership of NJTEEA that make a special effort that results in positive reflection of Technology & Engineering Education outside of the profession."

Congratulations Mr. Crannell!

#RandolphSchools #RandolphPride

post_text:
Randolph High School Orchestra Director Eric Schaberg spent many hours organizing this beautiful arrangement of Beethoven's classic "Ode to Joy" as a final good bye from the Orchestra Department. The composition, also known as "The Song of Brotherhood," seems rather appropriate during this time in our history! Thank you Mr. Schaberg and our RHS orchestra students for performing this moving and inspiring piece.

#RandolphSchools #RandolphPride

Virtual Graduation

Good afternoon Randolph families, community members, and students. You are invited to attend Randolph High School's virtual graduation ceremony to celebrate the Class of 2020. The event will be held tomorrow Thursday, June 18, 2020 and will start at approximately 6:30 PM. Please note that approximately 14 minutes at the beginning of the ceremony will be a photo montage.

We look forward to welcoming our students and families to the first ever virtual commencement ceremony for the Class of 2020!

The link to attend the event can be found below:

https://bit.ly/2UQbzgn

#RandolphSchools #RandolphPride

The Randolph High School administrative team will share their plans in the coming days and weeks as these plans continue to unfold with new guidance from state and local health officials.

post_text:
The Randolph Township School District condemns in the strongest terms possible the racist remarks that were recently posted on social media by some of our students. The remarks and behavior are antithetical to everything we stand for as a school district and as a community. The matter has been turned over to the Randolph Township Police Department who are currently investigating the matter and have directed the school district to refrain from any further investigating at this time.

Sincerely,

Jennifer Fano

post_text:
RHS Girls Lacrosse Makes a Sweet Donation

The Randolph High School Girls Lacrosse team, coaches and booster club decided to forgo their annual fundraising efforts to help bring joy to healthcare workers fighting COVID-19. They proudly donated their entire stockpile of 3,360 chocolate bars which the team had previously purchased to raise money for their program. The chocolate bars were delivered to three area hospitals: Morristown, Saint Barnabas and Chilton Medical Centers. The team and coaches worked with hospital administration to coordinate distribution amongst the frontline healthcare workers.

In a joint statement from the team: "We appreciate our healthcare workers for the risks and sacrifices they have made to take care of our community. We donated the chocolate bars as a gesture of our gratitude for their acts of selflessness and heroic work. Our hope is that this small act of kindness brings a moment of sweetness to their unimaginable days."

Thank you Randolph Girls LAX for making this generous donation!

#RandolphSchools #RandolphPride

post_text:
Manny Samaniego is a student at Center Grove Elementary and is already an accomplished pianist. Inspired by his mother, he decided to use his talent to spread joy to our healthcare workers fighting COVID-19 on the front line. "The name of the piece that I was playing is called "Dusk." I chose to play this song because it reminded me of my mom who is a nurse anesthetist and all the nurses in the world who are sacrificing their lives helping sick people because of coronavirus."

Manny has been playing the piano for three years and loves to study math and reading in school. In addition to his musical abilities, he is actively involved in athletics. He participates in football, basketball, wrestling, and lacrosse.

Thank you Manny for coming up with this idea and sharing your incredible abilities with the world. We hope that your piece will continue to be shared and inspire others during this time of uncertainty.

#RandolphSchools #RandolphPride

post_text:
Randolph Families,

New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy announced today, April 16, 2020 that all schools in New Jersey will be closed until at least May 15, 2020. In a statement by the Governor “We need to be guided by where the facts on the ground, science, and public health take us. That means it will not be safe to reopen our schools for at least another four weeks.”

The district will continue to implement its extended health-related school closure plan during this time. We will be issuing a parent survey in the near future to solicit feedback as we continue to reflect upon virtual instruction and prepare for potential further school closure. We are extremely appreciative of the dedicated efforts of our staff, students, and families as we navigate these challenges together.

Sincerely,

Jennifer Fano

post_text:
Randolph High School’s varsity softball team came up with a creative way to stay connected. The students made a video to help spread some positivity during the closure. Student athletes Emily Spingarn, Katelynn Oh, Amanda Flynn, and Alexis Shaunessy were all very excited to put together this video with their teammates. “We waited an entire year to play again and now that we are stuck inside we found another way to have a catch. We felt like this was a good way to keep everyone motivated and working so that we are ready for the season whenever that is. No matter if you are a freshman or a senior, we wanted to stir excitement and anticipation for this season. This video was a fun way to build team chemistry all throughout the program. We know that no matter what obstacles occur, there is always time to practice and study the game.”

Great job Rams!

#RandolphSchools #RandolphPride

If you need assistance getting connected to the parent portal or have questions on the form, please submit using the instructions under the Genesis: Parents section of our website.

Thank you in advance for participating in this important survey.

post_text:
Under the direction of the health department, all non-essential events have been suspended at this time effective immediately today March 12, 2020. In a formal statement by Governor Phil Murphy at 1:54 PM he said, “Today, I am recommending the cancellation of all public gatherings of 250 + people, including parades, concerts, and sporting events. Social distancing works. This is our best chance to mitigate the chance of exposure and rapid spread of COVID-19.”

Randolph Middle School’s production of Mary Poppins has been cancelled for this evening, Friday, and Saturday. The Community School’s After Care program will continue as scheduled. As new information or guidance is available, we will update the community.

#randolphschools #randolphpride

post_text:
Boys Ice Hockey Wins State Championship

Randolph Boys Ice Hockey went up against Ridge High School at the Prudential Center this evening in Newark. Your Rams dominated most of the game maintaining a commanding 2-0 lead. However, the opposing Devils didn't give up scoring an impressive 2 goals late in the third period. Despite Ridge's comeback, your Rams ultimately prevailed in overtime defeating the Devils 3-2 claiming the NJSIAA Group B State Championship!

Congratulations! What an amazing night for Randolph Athletics!

#randolphschools #randolphpride

post_text:
Puppet Palooza

Ironia Elementary art teacher Heather Turner knows what it's like to be a student in one of her classes. She was once a student at Ironia herself. Ms. Turner went from an intelligent, ambitious, and creative young Randolph student to become an equally impactful Randolph educator. She is passing on the legacy of her former teachers and has continued many of the traditions that she experienced in her own classroom.

One of the traditions passed down to her was the Puppet Palooza Showcase. Students spend countless hours working on puppets starting in the 4th grade and then finish their puppets in the 5th grade. The puppets are built from each student’s imagination, guided by the elements of art and principles of design they have learned over the years. The show showcases how students continue to grow from 4th grade into 5th grade.

We are grateful to Ms. Turner for continuing this amazing tradition at Ironia. The puppets are extremely creative and it's amazing to see the transformation over time.

#randolphschools #randolphpride

post_text:
Congratulations to Christine Petrat who was sworn in today as Randolph Township School's new Board of Education member by district Business Administrator Gerald Eckert. Ms. Petrat received her Bachelor’s degree in Social Work from Rutgers University and her Master of Social Work degree from Fordham University. She is currently a clinical social worker for the Mount Arlington Board of Education and has over 15 years of experience helping children in schools and other settings. Ms. Petrat is a member of the National Association of Social Workers. She has two children who attend Randolph High School. Her son Ian plays the trumpet in the marching band, wind ensemble, and jazz band. He is also a member of the varsity tennis program. Her son Nate was one of the first students in the Realizing Individual Student Excellence (R.I.S.E.) program.

Welcome to the Board of Education Ms. Petrat.

#randolphschools #randolphpride

post_text:
Maureen Coultas opened Hope's Promise Equine Assisted Activities Programs, a PATH International Center, in Chester, New Jersey in 2012. Since then, both individuals and groups have been experiencing the healing of horses through Therapeutic Riding and Equine Assisted Activities.

She visited Randolph Middle School's PAWS Club this past week and brought along her special guest Michelangelo to visit with students. Michelangelo is a miniature therapy horse. Ms. Coultas brings him and other therapy animals to schools to help students learn more about the value they bring to both people with special needs as well as individuals who are able bodied.

Thank you Ms. Coultas for coming to speak with our students and for all that you do in your amazing organization.

To learn more about Hope's Promise Farm

http://www.hopespromisefarm.com:

#randolphschools #randolphpride
text:
Maureen Coultas opened Hope's Promise Equine Assisted Activities Programs, a PATH International Center, in Chester, New Jersey in 2012. Since then, both individuals and groups have been experiencing the healing of horses through Therapeutic Riding and Equine Assisted Activities.

She visited Randolph Middle School's PAWS Club this past week and brought along her special guest Michelangelo to visit with students. Michelangelo is a miniature therapy horse. Ms. Coultas brings him and other therapy animals to schools to help students learn more about the value they bring to both people with special needs as well as individuals who are able bodied.

Thank you Ms. Coultas for coming to speak with our students and for all that you do in your amazing organization.

To learn more about Hope's Promise Farm

http://www.hopespromisefarm.com:

post_text:
Dr. Angelica Allen-McMillan, Interim Morris County Executive Superintendent of Schools and Dr. Linda Eno, Assistant Commissioner for the New Jersey Department of Education visited our schools today to tour our buildings, connect with our administrators, and interact with both teachers and students. The day began at Fernbrook Elementary where our honored guests met with 1st graders during math lessons and Kindergarten students during choice time. At the middle school, there were visits to the greenhouse, auditorium, and robotics classroom. Finally, at the high school, they were able to see our Option II program, computer science classrooms, and culinary arts kitchen.

We are honored and privileged to have had these amazing leaders in education interact with our students and faculty today! Thank you for coming to see all of the innovative opportunities provided to students across our district.

#randolphschools #randolphpride

post_text:
Ram Camp Information Session

The second Ram Camp Information Session will be held on Friday, February 7 at 7PM in the Randolph Middle School Auditorium. Ram Camp is the district’s new summer camp for children in grades Pre-K through 9. Previously, the summer camp offering was offered by grade level as Camp Summer Stars, Camp Summer Kids, and Camp Discovery, and offered at Randolph Middle School and Shongum Elementary School. All three camps now unite as Ram Camp and will all be housed at Randolph Middle School. Children will be broken into different divisions based on grade level. The inaugural Ram Camp will run from June 22 through August 14 and is available in weekly installments. Rates for camp, as well as planned field trips, are available on the district website, located here.

Registration is now open at rtnj.schoolcashonline.com. Register now to lock in early bird pricing, available through the end of February.

#randolphschools #randolphpride

post_text:
The Jazz Ensembles of Randolph Middle School and Randolph High School held their 8th Annual Jazz Coffee House fundraiser on Wednesday, January 29th in the Randolph High School Commons. Guests were served all-you-can-eat desserts, coffee, tea, and hot chocolate. Performances featured the music of George Gershwin, Count Basie, Buddy Rich Charles Mingus, and others.

The Jazz Coffee House event was sponsored by the Randolph Band Parents Association and Randolph Rotary. All proceeds from the event will fund educational opportunities for Randolph Middle and High School jazz musicians.

Thank you to our talented student musicians and staff for helping to make this night a tremendous success. Your leadership helps to provide additional opportunities for students in the performing arts at Randolph.

#randolphschools #randolphpride
